case_name: M/s Pannalal Binjrai v. Union of India

facts.text: Petitions Nos. 97 and 97A of 1956 filed by Ms. Pannalal Binjrai and R. B. Jamuna Das Chowdhury under Article 32 challenging transfers under s.5(7A).

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are M s. pannalal Binjrai, Oilmill owners, merchants and companymission agents, carrying on business at Sahibganj in the district of Santhal Pargans, having their branch at 94 Lower Chitpur Road, Culcutta, petitioner No. 1, and R. B. Jamuna Das Chowdhury, resident of the same place and erstwhile karta of the Hindu undivided family, which carried on business in the name and style of M S. Pannalal Binj

facts.text: Before September 28, 1954, petitioners in Nos. 97,97A assessed by Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Patna.

anchor.surface_text: petetioner No. 2. Before September 28, 1954, they, being assessed by the Income-tax officer, Special Circle, Patna.

facts.text: Central Board of Revenue transferred cases of petitioners Nos. 97,97A to ITO Central Circle XI, Calcutta on September 28, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On September 28, 1954, the Central Board of Revenue made an order -transferring their cases to the Income.tax Officer, Central Circle XI, Calcutta.

facts.text: Central Board of Revenue transferred case of petitioner No. 2 in 97A to ITO Central Circle VI, Delhi on January 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On January 22, 1955, the Central Board of Revenue transferred the cases of petitioner No. 2 to the Income-tax Officer Central Circle VI,Delhi,

facts.text: Central Board of Revenue transferred case of petitioner No. 1 in 97 to ITO Central Circle VI, Delhi on July 12, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: and on July 12, 1955, it similarly transferred the cases of petitioner No. I to the same officer.

facts.text: Petitioner in Petition No.44/56 is Shri A. L. Sud, sole proprietor of 14/B. Amritlal Sud Construction, residing in Calcutta since 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner in Petition No.44/56 is Shrii A. L. sud, the sole proprietor of 14/B. Amritlal Sud  Construction  who orginally belonged to Hoshiarpur district in the State of Punjab but has since 1948 been residing and carrying on business in Calcutta.

facts.text: Prior to June 29, 1955, petitioner in 44 assessed by ITO Special Survey Circle VII, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to June 29, 1959, he had been assessed to income-tax by the Income-tax Officer, Special Survey Circle VII, Calcutta.

facts.text: Central Board of Revenue transferred case of petitioner 44 to ITO Special Circle, Ambala on June 29, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On June 29, 1955, the Central Board of Revenue transferred his case to the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala,, and the said officer companytinued the proceedings in the transferred case

facts.text: Petitioners in 85/56 are Ms. Bhagwan Das Sud Sons, merchants in rosin and turpentine at Hoshiarpur.

anchor.surface_text: Petition No. 85/56 was filed by M s. Bhagwan Das Sud Sons, Merchants, Hoshiarpur, carrying on business in rosin and turpentine there.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax transferred case of 85/56 from ITO Hoshiarpur to ITO Special Circle Ambala on October 20, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Before October 20, 1953, they were being assessed by the Income-tax Officer,, Hoshiarpur, but on that date their case was transferred under s. 5  7A  of the Act by the Commissioner of Income-tax to the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala.

facts.text: Petitioners in 86,87,88,111,112,158 are Amritsar group, directors of Hindustan Embroidery Mills Pvt Ltd and others.

anchor.surface_text: These petitions may be companypendiously described as the Amritsar group. The petitioner in Petition No. 86/56 is Sardar Gurdial Singh, son of S. Narain Singh. The petitioner in Petition No. 87/56 is Dr. Sarmukh Singh, son of S. Narain Singh.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax transferred Amritsar group cases from ITO A Ward/F Ward Amritsar to ITO Special Circle Amritsar on or about June 29, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: but their cases were transferred on or about June 29, 1953, from the Income-tax Officer, A Ward, Amritsar, to the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Amritsar.

facts.text: Petitioner in 211-215 is Nandram Agarwalla, sole proprietor of Sriram Jhabarmull at Kalimpong with branch Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Though separately filed, the petitioner in each of them is the same individuals Nandram Agarwalla, who is the sole proprietor Of a business which he carries on under the name and style of I Sriram Jhabarmull.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax Central Calcutta transferred Sriram Jhabarmull cases to ITO Central Circle IV Calcutta on July 27, 1946 under s.5(7A).

anchor.surface_text: on July 27, 1946, orders were passed by the Commissioner of Income- tax Central, Calcutta, under s. 5  7A  transferring the cases of the petitioner to the Income-tax Officer, Central Circle IV, Calcutta.

facts.text: Petitioner in 225-229 is Kalloor Siddannal, commission agent in Raichur, Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner in each of them is the same individual, one Kalloor Siddannal who resides and carries on business in Raichur in the State of Hyderabad as companymission agent and distributor of agricultural products.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax Hyderabad transferred Raichur group case to ITO Special Circle Hyderabad on December 21, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On December 21, 1953, however, the Commissioner of Income- tax Hyderabad, issued a numberification under S. 5  7  ordering that the case of the petitioner should be transferred from the Additional income-tax Officer, Raichur, to the Income- tax Officer, Special Circle, Hyderabad.

facts.text: Another transfer order by Commissioner Hyderabad under s.5(7A) and s.64(5)(b) shortly before May 19, 1955 back to ITO Raichur.

anchor.surface_text: It appears, however, that shortly before May 19, 1955, the Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad, made another order under s. 5  7A  and s. 64  5  b  of the Act transferring all the cases of the petitioner to the main Income-tax Officer, Raichur.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Bhagwati J. on December 21, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: 1956. December 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-These petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution raise a companymon question of law whether s. 5  7A  of the Indian Income-tax Act,

facts.text: Section 5(7A) inserted by Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1940 (XL of 1940).

anchor.surface_text: This sub-section was inserted by s. 3 of the Indian Income- tax Amendment Act, 1940  XL of 1940  which was passed as a result of the decision of the Bombay High Court in Dayaldas Kushiram v. Commissioner of Income-tax,  Central  I.L.R. 194o Bom. 650,

facts.text: Explanation added to s.5(7A) by Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1956 (XXVI of 1956).

anchor.surface_text: By the Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1956  XXVI of 1956  an explanation was added to s. 5 7A  in the terms following as a result of the decision of this Court in Bidi Supply Co. v- The Union of India 1  Explanation

facts.text: Court holds s.5(7A) not ultra vires Articles 14 and 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that s. 5  7A  of the Act is number violative of Art. 14 of the Constitution and also does number impose any unreasonable restriction on the fundamental right to carry on trade or business enshrined in Art. 19  1   g  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitions dismissed as transfers valid and not discriminatory.

anchor.surface_text: The orders of transfer made by the Commissioner of Income- tax or the Central Board of Revenue, as the case may be, against the three groups of petitioners, viz., Sriram Jhabarmull group, the Raichur group and the Amritsar group, cannot, therefore, be challenged by them as unconstitutional and void

holdings.text: s. 5(7A) of the Act is not violative of Art. 14 of the Constitution and also does not impose any unreasonable restriction on the fundamental right to carry on trade or business enshrined in Art. 19(1)(g) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that s. 5  7A  of the Act is number violative of Art. 14 of the Constitution and also does number impose any unreasonable restriction on the fundamental right to carry on trade or business enshrined in Art. 19  1   g  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power under s.5(7A) guided by tax collection exigencies and administrative convenience; reasonable classification based on case complexities; vested in high officials; minor inconvenience not violating rights; distinguishes from fundamental rights discretion.

holdings.text: Right under s.64(1) and (2) is not absolute but subject to exigencies of tax collection and overridden by valid transfers under s.5(7A).

anchor.surface_text: The position, therefore, is that the determination of the, question whether a particular Income-tax Officer should assess the case of the assessee depends on  1  the companyvenience of the assessee as posited in s. 64  1  and  2  of the Act, and  2  the exigencies of tax companylection and it would be open to -the Commissioner of Income-tax and the Central Board of Revenue who are the highest amongst the Income-tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.64 provides convenience subject to tax exigencies; transfers necessary for efficient assessment in complex cases; supported by prior interpretations emphasizing practicability.

holdings.text: Omnibus wholesale orders of transfer are valid under s.5(7A) read with its Explanation.

anchor.surface_text: it follows, therefore, that the omnibus wholesale orders of transfer made against the petitioners by the Commissioner of Income-tax or the Central Board of Revenue, as the case may be, are saved by the explanation to s. 5 7A  and are number unconstitutional and void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation defines 'case' to include all pending and future proceedings for any year; overcomes Bidi Supply majority's construction; allows comprehensive transfers without reissuing notices.

holdings.text: Pre-Constitution orders of transfer under s.5(7A) cannot be challenged as unconstitutional under Art.13.

anchor.surface_text: It is settled that Art. 13 of the Constitution has numberretrospective effect and if, therefore, any action was taken before the companymencement of the Constitution in pursuance of the provisions of any law which was a valid law at the time when such action was taken, such action cannot be challenged.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.13 has no retrospective effect; pre-Constitution actions under valid laws immune from post-Constitution fundamental rights challenges; cites Keshavan Madhava Menon.

holdings.text: Petitioners disentitled to relief under Art.32 due to acquiescence in transfers.

anchor.surface_text: numbere of the petitioners raised any objection to their cases being transferred in the manner stated above and in fact submitted to the jurisdiction of the Income-tax Officers to whom their cases had been transferred. It was only after our decision in Bidi Supply Co. v. The Union of India,  supra , was pronounced on March 20, 1956, that these petitioners woke up.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No objection raised; submitted to jurisdiction until after Bidi Supply; acquiescence disentitles Art.32 relief.

holdings.text: Individual transfer orders against petitioners not discriminatory or mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to these circumstances which are disclosed in the affidavits of Shri V. Gouri Shankar... it is clear that the transfer... were made as a matter of administrative convenience only.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavits show transfers for admin convenience, evasion checks, workload balancing, interrelated cases; no evidence of discrimination; convenience measures like local exams provided.

holdings.text: Petitions dismissed as transfers valid and not unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: The orders of transfer made by the Commissioner of Income- tax or the Central Board of Revenue, as the case may be, against the three groups of petitioners, viz., Sriram Jhabarmull group, the Raichur group and the Amritsar group, cannot, therefore, be challenged by them as unconstitutional and void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of above holdings to facts of groups.

holdings.text: Principles of natural justice should be followed where possible before transfers under s.5(7A): notice, opportunity, brief reasons.

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, before we leave this topic observe that it would be prudent if the principles of natural justice are, followed, where circumstances permit, before any order of transfer under s. 5  7A  of the Act is made by the Commissioner of Income-tax or the Central Board of Revenue, as the case may be, and numberice is given to the party affected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prudent practice for fairness; contrasts with s.64(3); helps review but not mandatory.
